Situation1: A minor misunderstanding about weekend plans just arose.
Expectation2: Deliver packages on time and to the correct address
Situation2: A package arrives slightly later than expected, but still within the same day
Story:
I stared at my phone, reading Mia’s text again: “I thought we were going to your parents’ this weekend, not mine?” I could sense her disappointment, and I knew I needed to call her, talk it out, and clear up the confusion before it grew into something bigger. As her boyfriend, I always tried to be the one who smoothed things over, who made sure we were on the same page. But just as I was about to dial her number, my work phone buzzed. The dispatcher’s message was clear: “Package for 14B just arrived—customer requested ASAP delivery. Please confirm drop-off within the hour.”

I glanced at the clock. If I left now, I could make the delivery on time, keep my record spotless, and avoid any complaints. But that meant putting off the call with Mia, letting her stew in uncertainty a little longer. My chest tightened as I weighed the expectations—be the reliable boyfriend who resolves misunderstandings, or the dependable delivery person who never misses a deadline. I stood there, phone in each hand, torn between two worlds, feeling the pressure mount with every passing second.
